comment._content: The Hon. Herbrand Charles Alexander (1888 - 1965) From the Wikipedia entry for his father, the 4th Earl of Caledon: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Alexander,_4th_Earl_of_Caledon "Lt.-Col. Hon. Herbrand Charles Alexander DSO (28 November 1888 – 6 May 1965), who fought with the 5th Lancers during the First World War and was mentioned in despatches three times, and in the Second World War as a Lieutenant Colonel of the Pioneer Corps. He married, firstly, Millicent Meredyth, only daughter of Sir Henry Meredyth, 5th Baronet, in 1919 (divorced 1927), and had issue: (i) Denis Alexander, 6th Earl of Caledon. He married, secondly, the Hon. Ada Kate Bellew (who died in 1994), daughter of the late Hon. Richard Eustace Bellew and granddaughter of Edward Bellew, 2nd Baron Bellew, in 1937." This would make him the older brother of Harold Alexander, the well-known commander of the 8th Army in the Second World War, afterwards Field Marshal the Right Honourable the Earl Alexander of Tunis: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Alexander,_1st_Earl_Alexande... His mother was Lady Elizabeth Graham-Toler, daughter of Hector Graham-Toler, 3rd Earl of Norbury. Google searches reveal an interest in horses and polo not unusual for a cavalry officer. The Peerage page: thepeerage.com/p8033.htm National Portrait Gallery images: www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp82960/hon-herb...

comment._content: Second of four sons of Hon. James Alexander, 4th Earl of Caledon (County Tyrone) Captain, 1st Life Guards, became a Major serving with the 4th Battalion, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers and fought in the Egyptian Campaign in 1882: Hon. Eric James Desmond Alexander, 5th Earl of Caledon (9 August 1885 – 10 July 1968) WWI Major, Life Guards Hon. Herbrand Charles Alexander DSO (28 November 1888 – 6 May 1965) WWI Lt-Col, Irish Lancers (Note: cavalry) Hon. Harold Rupert Leofric George Alexander, Earl Alexander of Tunis KG GCB OM GCMG CSI DSO MC CD PC PC(Can) (10 December 1891 – 16 June 1969) WWI Acting Lt.-Col. Irish Guards WWII Field Marshall Hon. William Sigismund Patrick Alexander DSO (16 November 1895 – 24 December 1972) WWI and WWII Irish Guards (Wikipedia articles) From The Irish Guards in the Great War, Vol. 2 Appendix A Rudyard Kipling 20th October 1916. D.S.O. to Captain the Hon. Harold Rupert Leofric George Alexander, M.C., 2nd Battalion, Irish Guards: “For conspicuous gallantry in action. He was the life and soul of the attack, and throughout the day led forward not only his own men but men of all regiments. He held the trenches gained in spite of heavy machine-gun fire.” 8th January 1918. D.S.O. to Lieutenant (Acting Captain) the Hon. William Sigismund Patrick Alexander, Irish Guards: “For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty. Whilst leading his company in an attack he came under heavy machine-gun fire from a concrete emplacement. He immediately led a successful attack through a gap in our barrage, and outflanked three gun positions, capturing three machine-guns and fourteen men. He then continued the attack, and seized his objective within the scheduled time, in spite of having to pass through our own barrage as well as that of the enemy. He set a splendid example of fearlessness and resource.” www.telelib.com/authors/K/KiplingRudyard/prose/IrishGuard...

comment._content:
A personal memoir published 2010
Herbrand Alexander (Author), Guy St John Williams (Editor) FIREBRAND - THE LIFE AND TIMES OF HERBRAND ALEXANDER, a limited edition of 500 copies. Herbrand Alexander of Caledon's nickname 'Firebrand' was gained on the racecourse, where his exploits were to gain him Irish amateur champion honours. Published only now, Firebrand Alexander's account of his war experiences could well be entitled 'Mons to Mons', his cavalry regiment having first seen action at Mons. His drastically depleted regiment it was that liberated Mons four long, terrible years later.  'Firebrand' also outlines this sportsman's life from his earliest soldiering days to the eve of his death in 1965. Rider, owner, trainer and breeder.
